Re ''Another Gain for Irish Peace'' (editorial, May 30):

Indeed, there is no requirement more important than creating a new, acceptable police service for Northern Ireland. The current police force, the Royal Ulster Constabulary, has since its inception in 1922 been in effect the armed wing of the Unionist Party. Its job was to keep Catholics in their place.

The Patten report -- if it is carried out in full -- can give Catholics hope that there could be a new beginning to policing in Northern Ireland. But already the British government is trying to betray Patten, thus endangering any new beginning.

Unless the new Northern Ireland Police Service is truly representative, accountable, impartial and committed to the protection of human rights, there will not be a lasting peace. The sectarian Royal Ulster Constabulary has always been a basic cause of the Troubles. (Rev.)
SEAN MC MANUS President, Irish National Caucus Washington, May 31, 2000
